column4: I asked in the xubuntu channel, but got no response: I'm having a problem with saving my wireless WPA passhprase using Xubuntu. I have "Start GNOME services" enabled, and I also installed "Seahorse" via Synaptics.
However, the NetworkManager is not saving my WPA passphrase. And the one time it did, it left it unprotected (plaintext, not a hash, like GNOME does.)
When I open up Seahorse, I cannot "change password" for the login key.
http://wicd.sourceforge.net/
I don't like wicd.
wicd stores your passphrase in plaintext in a global file, accessible by anyone.
odd, mine does not, it's sha2'd
what version of wicd?
i had endless troubles with wifi in networkmanager though, that's what prompted the switch
I've tried the latest version of wicd, and it's still stored in the wireless.conf file, unhashed.
what flags are you compiling with? that should not be default behavior
not compiling. Binary .deb from the wicd ppa.
hrm..i don't haev any advice there, i don't know what flags they use in their binary offerings
back to network manager...have you tried destroying it's local settings and restarting it?  maybe there are some conflicting preferences saved causing adverse behavior
in my home directory you mean?
yes, just a shot in the dark though
I did not have this problem on Ubuntu. It only gives me this issue on Xubuntu.
does xubuntu also use network-manager by default?(i've never used it and don't know)
check(or possibly destroy) /etc/NetworkManager settigns also
some user-settings could be conflicting with some system-wide settings specified there
I'll check them out.
